question.body: Osteogenesis imperfecta is usually caused by a mutation in collagen, in which the glycine is mutated into another residue. Changes in what structure might be associated with a this mutation

response.feedback: Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.
Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.

Correct. The structure is affected at all levels. Mutations from glycine amino acids to other amino acids prevent the organization of the gly-pro-x (glycine-proline-X) into a left-handed helix (secondary structure) leading to "coiled coil" collagen tertiary and quaternary structures. This ultimately leads to bones that crack too easily because of poorly organized collagen.
